content:
This is a nice clash, but it's a bit of a pain in Shortest mode because you have really inconsistent usage of newlines in your input and output.

You end up with errors like this in Shortest mode if you don't remove newlines from your output (in Ruby where this is manual):
"Found: (3) gEnd of line (\n)
Expected: Nothing"

Tests with input having a single extra newline (not a big deal):
T1, V2

Tests with input having TWO extra newlines (a big deal, causing errors):
V1, T2

Tests with output having a single extra newline (not a big deal)
V3, T5

I could edit it myself, but I thought it would be good to flag it with you instead so you'd know it was an issue. I could've saved 6 characters in Shortest mode if it weren't for V1 and T2, :P.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It's fun and interesting to code this puzzle. and it's working fine.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: because it's good

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good puzzle for me.

I would just remove the identifier mecanics, not really interesting in my opinion.
Beside that this game seems good enough for a quick clash of code.

Either specify in the details this is case-sensitive or make one of the examples illustrate the fact. Nobody enjoys having to hope the test cases align with the assumption they make before and after submission.

Thanks for the feedback; here is my reasoning:

The reason I have the identifier is so that (for example) if a player get the first 12 correct but the 13th one is wrong they can easily see that it’s the 13th one.
